Monitor for an attempt by a user to gain access to a network or computing resource, often by providing credentials that may search compromised systems to find and obtain insecurely stored credentials.
Monitor for unexpected windows registry key being accessed that may search compromised systems to find and obtain insecurely stored credentials.

Title: Account Discovery
Description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of valid accounts, usernames, or email addresses on a system or within a compromised environment. This information can help adversaries determine which accounts exist, which can aid in follow-on behavior such as brute-forcing, spear-phishing attacks, or account takeovers (e.g., Valid Accounts).Adversaries may use several methods to enumerate accounts, including abuse of existing tools, built-in commands, and potential misconfigurations that leak account names and roles or permissions in the targeted environment.For examples, cloud environments typically provide easily accessible interfaces to obtain user lists. On hosts, adversaries can use default PowerShell and other command line functionality to identify accounts. Information about email addresses and accounts may also be extracted by searching an infected systems files.

Mitigation.name: FIN13
Mitigation.description: FIN13 has enumerated all users and their roles from a victim's main treasury system.[1]

Mitigation.name: ShimRatReporter
Mitigation.description: ShimRatReporter listed all non-privileged and privileged accounts available on the machine.[2]

Mitigation.name: SolarWinds Compromise
Mitigation.description: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 obtained a list of users and their roles from an Exchange server using Get-ManagementRoleAssignment.[3]

Mitigation.name: Woody RAT
Mitigation.description: Woody RAT can identify administrator accounts on an infected machine.[4]

Mitigation.name: XCSSET
Mitigation.description: XCSSET attempts to discover accounts from various locations such as a user's Evernote, AppleID, Telegram, Skype, and WeChat data.[5]

Detection.detects: Monitor logs and other sources of command execution history for actions that could be taken to gather information about accounts, including the use of calls to cloud APIs that perform account discovery.System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment, and also to an extent in normal network operations. Therefore discovery data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Lateral Movement, based on the information obtained.

Monitor access to file resources that contain local accounts and groups information such as /etc/passwd, /Users directories, and the SAM database. If access requires high privileges, look for non-admin objects (such as users or processes) attempting to access restricted file resources.

Monitor for processes that can be used to enumerate user accounts and groups such as net.exe and net1.exe, especially when executed in quick succession.[7]Information may also be acquired through Windows system management tools such as Windows Management Instrumentation and PowerShell.

Title: Application Window Discovery
Description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of open application windows. Window listings could convey information about how the system is used.[1] For example, information about application windows could be used identify potential data to collect as well as identifying security tooling (Security Software Discovery) to evade.[2]Adversaries typically abuse system features for this type of enumeration. For example, they may gather information through native system features such as Command and Scripting Interpreter commands and Native API functions.

Mitigation.name: Aria-body
Mitigation.description: Aria-body has the ability to identify the titles of running windows on a compromised host.[3]

Mitigation.name: Attor
Mitigation.description: Attor can obtain application window titles and then determines which windows to perform Screen Capture on.[4]

Mitigation.name: Cadelspy
Mitigation.description: Cadelspy has the ability to identify open windows on the compromised host.[5]

Mitigation.name: Catchamas
Mitigation.description: Catchamas obtains application windows titles and then determines which windows to perform Screen Capture on.[6]

Mitigation.name: DarkWatchman
Mitigation.description: DarkWatchman reports window names along with keylogger information to provide application context.[1]

Mitigation.name: Duqu
Mitigation.description: The discovery modules used with Duqu can collect information on open windows.[7]

Mitigation.name: Flagpro
Mitigation.description: Flagpro can check the name of the window displayed on the system.[8]

Mitigation.name: FunnyDream
Mitigation.description: FunnyDream has the ability to discover application windows via execution of EnumWindows.[9]

Mitigation.name: Grandoreiro
Mitigation.description: Grandoreiro can identify installed security tools based on window names.[2]

Mitigation.name: HEXANE
Mitigation.description: HEXANE has used a PowerShell-based keylogging tool to capture the window title.[10]

Mitigation.name: HotCroissant
Mitigation.description: HotCroissant has the ability to list the names of all open windows on the infected host.[11]

Mitigation.name: InvisiMole
Mitigation.description: InvisiMole can enumerate windows and child windows on a compromised host.[12][13]

Mitigation.name: Kazuar
Mitigation.description: Kazuar gathers information about opened windows.[14]

Mitigation.name: Lazarus Group
Mitigation.description: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia obtains and sends to its C2 server the title of the window for each running process. The KilaAlfa keylogger also reports the title of the window in the foreground.[15][16][17]

Mitigation.name: Machete
Mitigation.description: Machete saves the window names.[18]

Mitigation.name: Metamorfo
Mitigation.description: Metamorfo can enumerate all windows on the victims machine.[19][20]

Mitigation.name: NetTraveler
Mitigation.description: NetTraveler reports window names along with keylogger information to provide application context.[21]

Mitigation.name: NETWIRE
Mitigation.description: NETWIRE can discover and close windows on controlled systems.[22]

Mitigation.name: NightClub
Mitigation.description: NightClub can use GetForegroundWindow to enumerate the active window.[23]

Mitigation.name: njRAT
Mitigation.description: njRAT gathers information about opened windows during the initial infection.[24]

Mitigation.name: PLEAD
Mitigation.description: PLEAD has the ability to list open windows on the compromised host.[25][25]

Mitigation.name: PoisonIvy
Mitigation.description: PoisonIvy captures window titles.[26]

Mitigation.name: PowerDuke
Mitigation.description: PowerDuke has a command to get text of the current foreground window.[27]

Mitigation.name: QakBot
Mitigation.description: QakBot has the ability to enumerate windows on a compromised host.[28]

Mitigation.name: Remexi
Mitigation.description: Remexi has a command to capture active windows on the machine and retrieve window titles.[29]

Mitigation.name: ROKRAT
Mitigation.description: ROKRAT can use  the GetForegroundWindow and GetWindowText APIs to discover where the user is typing.[30]

Mitigation.name: SILENTTRINITY
Mitigation.description: SILENTTRINITY can enumerate the active Window during keylogging through execution of GetActiveWindowTitle.[31]

Mitigation.name: SOUNDBITE
Mitigation.description: SOUNDBITE is capable of enumerating application windows.[32]

Mitigation.name: Trojan.Karagany
Mitigation.description: Trojan.Karagany can monitor the titles of open windows to identify specific keywords.[33]

Mitigation.name: WINERACK
Mitigation.description: WINERACK can enumerate active windows.[34]

Detection.detects: Monitor executed commands and arguments for actions that could be taken to gather system and network information. Information may also be acquired through Windows system management tools such as Windows Management Instrumentation and PowerShell.Note: Commands can also be obtained from Payload event field for PowerShell event id 4103. For PowerShell Module logging event id 4103, enable logging for module Microsoft.PowerShell.Management. Analytic 1 - Suspicious Commands  suspicious_commands = filter commands where event_id == "4103" AND  ((command_line LIKE '%Get-Process%' AND command_line_parameter LIKE '%mainWindowTitle%'))

Monitor for API calls (such as GetForegroundWindow()) that may attempt to get a listing of open application windows. GetForegroundWindow api returns a handle to the foreground window (the window with which the user is currently working). Other API calls relevant to Local Group discovery include  GetProcesses and GetForegroundWindow. GetProcesses api returns an array of type Process that represents all the process resources running on the local computer.Note: Most EDR tools do not support direct monitoring of API calls due to the sheer volume of calls produced by an endpoint but may have alerts or events that are based on abstractions of OS API calls. Dynamic malware analysis tools (i.e., sandboxes) can be used to trace the execution, including OS API calls, for a single PE binary.  Analytic 1 - Suspicious API Calls suspicious_apis = filter processes where ApiName LIKE '%GetProcesses%' OR ApiName LIKE '%GetForegroundWindow%'

Monitor for newly executed processes that may attempt to get a listing of open application windows. System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities based on the information obtained.Note: Event IDs are for Sysmon (Event ID 1 - process create) and Windows Security Log (Event ID 4688 - a new process has been created). Analytic 1 - Suspicious Processes suspicious_processes = filter process where   (event_id == "1" OR event_id == "4688") AND  (command_line LIKE '%Get-Process%' AND command_line LIKE '%mainWindowTitle%')

Title: Browser Information Discovery
Description: Adversaries may enumerate information about browsers to learn more about compromised environments. Data saved by browsers (such as bookmarks, accounts, and browsing history) may reveal a variety of personal information about users (e.g., banking sites, relationships/interests, social media, etc.) as well as details about internal network resources such as servers, tools/dashboards, or other related infrastructure.[1]Browser information may also highlight additional targets after an adversary has access to valid credentials, especially Credentials In Files associated with logins cached by a browser.Specific storage locations vary based on platform and/or application, but browser information is typically stored in local files and databases (e.g., %APPDATA%/Google/Chrome).[2]

Mitigation.name: APT38
Mitigation.description: APT38 has collected browser bookmark information to learn more about compromised hosts, obtain personal information about users, and acquire details about internal network resources.[3]

Mitigation.name: Calisto
Mitigation.description: Calisto collects information on bookmarks from Google Chrome.[4]

Mitigation.name: Chimera
Mitigation.description: Chimera has used type \\c$\Users\\Favorites\Links\Bookmarks bar\Imported From IE*citrix* for bookmark discovery.[5]

Mitigation.name: DarkWatchman
Mitigation.description: DarkWatchman can retrieve browser history.[6]

Mitigation.name: Dtrack
Mitigation.description: Dtrack can retrieve browser history.[7][8]

Mitigation.name: Empire
Mitigation.description: Empire has the ability to gather browser data such as bookmarks and visited sites.[9]

Mitigation.name: Fox Kitten
Mitigation.description: Fox Kitten has used Google Chrome bookmarks to identify internal resources and assets.[10]

Mitigation.name: Lizar
Mitigation.description: Lizar can retrieve browser history and database files.[11][12]

Mitigation.name: Machete
Mitigation.description: Machete retrieves the user profile data (e.g., browsers) from Chrome and Firefox browsers.[13]

Mitigation.name: Mafalda
Mitigation.description: Mafalda can collect the contents of the %USERPROFILE%\AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\LocalState file.[14]

Mitigation.name: MobileOrder
Mitigation.description: MobileOrder has a command to upload to its C2 server victim browser bookmarks.[15]

Mitigation.name: PowerLess
Mitigation.description: PowerLess has a browser info stealer module that can read Chrome and Edge browser database files.[16]

Mitigation.name: SUGARDUMP
Mitigation.description: SUGARDUMP has collected browser bookmark and history information.[17]

Detection.detects: Monitor executed commands and arguments for actions that could be taken to gather browser information, such as local files and databases (e.g., %APPDATA%/Google/Chrome).[2] Remote access tools with built-in features may interact directly using APIs to gather information. Information may also be acquired through system management tools such as Windows Management Instrumentation and PowerShell.

Monitor for unusual access to stored browser data, such as local files and databases (e.g., %APPDATA%/Google/Chrome).[2] Rather than viewing these events in isolation, this activity may highlight a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Collection and Exfiltration.
Monitor for processes with arguments that may be associated with gathering browser information, such as local files and databases (e.g., %APPDATA%/Google/Chrome).[2]

Title: Cloud Infrastructure Discovery
Description: An adversary may attempt to discover infrastructure and resources that are available within an infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS) environment. This includes compute service resources such as instances, virtual machines, and snapshots as well as resources of other services including the storage and database services.Cloud providers offer methods such as APIs and commands issued through CLIs to serve information about infrastructure. For example, AWS provides a DescribeInstances API within the Amazon EC2 API that can return information about one or more instances within an account, the ListBuckets API that returns a list of all buckets owned by the authenticated sender of the request, the HeadBucket API to determine a buckets existence along with access permissions of the request sender, or the GetPublicAccessBlock API to retrieve access block configuration for a bucket.[1][2][3][4] Similarly, GCP's Cloud SDK CLI provides the gcloud compute instances list command to list all Google Compute Engine instances in a project [5], and Azure's CLI command az vm list lists details of virtual machines.[6] In addition to API commands, adversaries can utilize open source tools to discover cloud storage infrastructure through Wordlist Scanning.[7]An adversary may enumerate resources using a compromised user's access keys to determine which are available to that user.[8] The discovery of these available resources may help adversaries determine their next steps in the Cloud environment, such as establishing Persistence.[9]An adversary may also use this information to change the configuration to make the bucket publicly accessible, allowing data to be accessed without authentication. Adversaries have also may use infrastructure discovery APIs such as DescribeDBInstances to determine size, owner, permissions, and network ACLs of database resources. [10] Adversaries can use this information to determine the potential value of databases and discover the requirements to access them. Unlike in Cloud Service Discovery, this technique focuses on the discovery of components of the provided services rather than the services themselves.

Mitigation.name: Pacu
Mitigation.description: Pacu can enumerate AWS infrastructure, such as EC2 instances.[11]

Detection.detects: Monitor cloud logs for API calls and other potentially unusual activity related to cloud data object storage enumeration. Discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Collection and Exfiltration, based on the information obtained.

Monitor cloud logs for API calls and other potentially unusual activity related to cloud instance enumeration. Discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Collection and Exfiltration, based on the information obtained.

Monitor cloud logs for API calls and other potentially unusual activity related to snapshot enumeration. Discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Collection and Exfiltration, based on the information obtained.

Monitor cloud logs for API calls and other potentially unusual activity related to block object storage enumeration. Discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Collection and Exfiltration, based on the information obtained.

Title: Cloud Service Dashboard
Description: An adversary may use a cloud service dashboard GUI with stolen credentials to gain useful information from an operational cloud environment, such as specific services, resources, and features. For example, the GCP Command Center can be used to view all assets, findings of potential security risks, and to run additional queries, such as finding public IP addresses and open ports.[1]Depending on the configuration of the environment, an adversary may be able to enumerate more information via the graphical dashboard than an API. This allows the adversary to gain information without making any API requests.

Mitigation.name: User Account Management
Mitigation.description: Enforce the principle of least-privilege by limiting dashboard visibility to only the resources required. This may limit the discovery value of the dashboard in the event of a compromised account.

Detection.detects: Monitor for newly constructed logon behavior across cloud service management consoles.[2]
Correlate other security systems with login information, such as user accounts, IP addresses, and login names.[2]

Title: Cloud Service Discovery
Description: An adversary may attempt to enumerate the cloud services running on a system after gaining access. These methods can differ from platform-as-a-service (PaaS), to infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS), or software-as-a-service (SaaS). Many services exist throughout the various cloud providers and can include Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery (CI/CD), Lambda Functions, Azure AD, etc. They may also include security services, such as AWS GuardDuty and Microsoft Defender for Cloud, and logging services, such as AWS CloudTrail and Google Cloud Audit Logs.Adversaries may attempt to discover information about the services enabled throughout the environment. Azure tools and APIs, such as the Azure AD Graph API and Azure Resource Manager API, can enumerate resources and services, including applications, management groups, resources and policy definitions, and their relationships that are accessible by an identity.[1][2]For example, Stormspotter is an open source tool for enumerating and constructing a graph for Azure resources and services, and Pacu is an open source AWS exploitation framework that supports several methods for discovering cloud services.[3][4]Adversaries may use the information gained to shape follow-on behaviors, such as targeting data or credentials from enumerated services or evading identified defenses through Disable or Modify Tools or Disable or Modify Cloud Logs.

Mitigation.name: AADInternals
Mitigation.description: AADInternals can enumerate information about a variety of cloud services, such as Office 365 and Sharepoint instances or OpenID Configurations.[5]

Mitigation.name: Pacu
Mitigation.description: Pacu can enumerate AWS services, such as CloudTrail and CloudWatch.[4]

Mitigation.name: ROADTools
Mitigation.description: ROADTools can enumerate Azure AD applications and service principals.[6]

Detection.detects: Cloud service discovery techniques will likely occur throughout an operation where an adversary is targeting cloud-based systems and services. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities based on the information obtained.Normal, benign system and network events that look like cloud service discovery may be uncommon, depending on the environment and how they are used. Monitor cloud service usage for anomalous behavior that may indicate adversarial presence within the environment.

Title: Cloud Storage Object Discovery
Description: Adversaries may enumerate objects in cloud storage infrastructure. Adversaries may use this information during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including requesting all or specific objects from cloud storage.  Similar to File and Directory Discovery on a local host, after identifying available storage services (i.e. Cloud Infrastructure Discovery) adversaries may access the contents/objects stored in cloud infrastructure.Cloud service providers offer APIs allowing users to enumerate objects stored within cloud storage. Examples include ListObjectsV2 in AWS [1] and List Blobs in Azure[2] .

Mitigation.name: Pacu
Mitigation.description: Pacu can enumerate AWS storage services, such as S3 buckets and Elastic Block Store volumes.[3]

Mitigation.name: Peirates
Mitigation.description: Peirates can list AWS S3 buckets.[4]

Detection.detects: Monitor for unusual queries to the cloud provider's storage service. Activity originating from unexpected sources may indicate improper permissions are set that is allowing access to data. Additionally, detecting failed attempts by a user for a certain object, followed by escalation of privileges by the same user, and access to the same object may be an indication of suspicious activity.

Monitor cloud logs for API calls used for file or object enumeration for unusual activity. System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Collection and Exfiltration, based on the information obtained.

Title: Container and Resource Discovery
Description: Adversaries may attempt to discover containers and other resources that are available within a containers environment. Other resources may include images, deployments, pods, nodes, and other information such as the status of a cluster.These resources can be viewed within web applications such as the Kubernetes dashboard or can be queried via the Docker and Kubernetes APIs.[1][2] In Docker, logs may leak information about the environment, such as the environments configuration, which services are available, and what cloud provider the victim may be utilizing. The discovery of these resources may inform an adversarys next steps in the environment, such as how to perform lateral movement and which methods to utilize for execution.

Mitigation.name: Hildegard
Mitigation.description: Hildegard has used masscan to search for kubelets and the kubelet API for additional running containers.[3]

Mitigation.name: Peirates
Mitigation.description: Peirates can enumerate Kubernetes pods in a given namespace.[4]

Mitigation.name: TeamTNT
Mitigation.description: TeamTNT has checked for running containers with docker ps and for specific container names with docker inspect.[5] TeamTNT has also searched for Kubernetes pods running in a local network.[6]

Detection.detects: Monitor logs for actions that could be taken to gather information about container infrastructure, including the use of discovery API calls by new or unexpected users. Monitor account activity logs to see actions performed and activity associated with the Kubernetes dashboard and other web applications.

Monitor logs for actions that could be taken to gather information about pods, including the use of discovery API calls by new or unexpected users. Monitor account activity logs to see actions performed and activity associated with the Kubernetes dashboard and other web applications.

Title: Debugger Evasion
Description: Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid debuggers. Debuggers are typically used by defenders to trace and/or analyze the execution of potential malware payloads.[1]Debugger evasion may include changing behaviors based on the results of the checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a debugged environment. Similar to Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion, if the adversary detects a debugger, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for debugger artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads.Specific checks will vary based on the target and/or adversary, but may involve Native API function calls such as IsDebuggerPresent() and  NtQueryInformationProcess(), or manually checking the BeingDebugged flag of the Process Environment Block (PEB). Other checks for debugging artifacts may also seek to enumerate hardware breakpoints, interrupt assembly opcodes, time checks, or measurements if exceptions are raised in the current process (assuming a present debugger would "swallow" or handle the potential error).[2][3][4]Adversaries may use the information learned from these debugger checks during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors. Debuggers can also be evaded by detaching the process or flooding debug logs with meaningless data via messages produced by looping Native API function calls such as OutputDebugStringW().[5][6]

Mitigation.name: AsyncRAT
Mitigation.description: AsyncRAT can use the CheckRemoteDebuggerPresent function to detect the presence of a debugger.[7]

Mitigation.name: Black Basta
Mitigation.description: The Black Basta dropper can check system flags, CPU registers, CPU instructions, process timing, system libraries, and APIs to determine if a debugger is present.[8]

Mitigation.name: Bumblebee
Mitigation.description: Bumblebee can search for tools used in static analysis.[9]

Mitigation.name: DarkTortilla
Mitigation.description: DarkTortilla can detect debuggers by using functions such as DebuggerIsAttached and DebuggerIsLogging. DarkTortilla can also detect profilers by verifying the COR_ENABLE_PROFILING environment variable is present and active.[10]

Mitigation.name: DRATzarus
Mitigation.description: DRATzarus can use IsDebuggerPresent to detect whether a debugger is present on a victim.[11]

Mitigation.name: Mafalda
Mitigation.description: Mafalda can search for debugging tools on a compromised host.[12]

Mitigation.name: Operation Dream Job
Mitigation.description: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used tools that used the IsDebuggerPresent call to detect debuggers.[11]

Mitigation.name: ROKRAT
Mitigation.description: ROKRAT can check for debugging tools.[13][14][15]

Mitigation.name: Saint Bot
Mitigation.description: Saint Bot has used is_debugger_present as part of its environmental checks.[16]

Mitigation.name: ThiefQuest
Mitigation.description: ThiefQuest uses a function named is_debugging to perform anti-debugging logic. The function invokes sysctl checking the returned value of P_TRACED. ThiefQuest also calls ptrace with the PTRACE_DENY_ATTACH flag to prevent debugging.[5]

Detection.detects: Monitor debugger logs for signs of abnormal and potentially malicious activity.

Monitor executed commands and arguments that may employ various means to detect and avoid debugged environments. Detecting actions related to debugger identification may be difficult depending on the adversary's implementation and monitoring required.

Monitor for API calls (such as IsDebuggerPresent()) that may employ various means to detect and avoid debugged environments. Detecting actions related to debugger identification may be difficult depending on the adversary's implementation and monitoring required.

Monitoring for suspicious processes being spawned that gather a variety of system information or perform other forms of Discovery, especially in a short period of time, may aid in detection. Debugger related system checks will likely occur in the first steps of an operation but may also occur throughout as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as lateral movement, based on the information obtained.

Title: Device Driver Discovery
Description: Adversaries may attempt to enumerate local device drivers on a victim host. Information about device drivers may highlight various insights that shape follow-on behaviors, such as the function/purpose of the host, present security tools (i.e. Security Software Discovery) or other defenses (e.g., Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion), as well as potential exploitable vulnerabilities (e.g., Exploitation for Privilege Escalation).Many OS utilities may provide information about local device drivers, such as driverquery.exe and the EnumDeviceDrivers() API function on Windows.[1][2] Information about device drivers (as well as associated services, i.e., System Service Discovery) may also be available in the Registry.[3]On Linux/macOS, device drivers (in the form of kernel modules) may be visible within /dev or using utilities such as lsmod and modinfo.[4][5][6]

Mitigation.name: HOPLIGHT
Mitigation.description: HOPLIGHT can enumerate device drivers located in the registry at HKLM\Software\WBEM\WDM.[7]

Mitigation.name: Remsec
Mitigation.description: Remsec has a plugin to detect active drivers of some security products.[8]

Detection.detects: Monitor executed commands (lsmod, driverquery, etc.) with arguments highlighting potentially malicious attempts to enumerate device drivers.
Monitor for API calls (such as EnumDeviceDrivers()) that may attempt to gather information about local device drivers.
Monitor processes (lsmod, driverquery.exe, etc.) for events that may highlight potentially malicious attempts to enumerate device drivers.

Monitor for attempts to access information stored in the Registry about devices and their associated drivers, such as values under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\HardwareProfiles.[3]

Title: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: Adversaries may attempt to gather information on domain trust relationships that may be used to identify lateral movement opportunities in Windows multi-domain/forest environments. Domain trusts provide a mechanism for a domain to allow access to resources based on the authentication procedures of another domain.[1] Domain trusts allow the users of the trusted domain to access resources in the trusting domain. The information discovered may help the adversary conduct SID-History Injection, Pass the Ticket, and Kerberoasting.[2][3] Domain trusts can be enumerated using the DSEnumerateDomainTrusts() Win32 API call, .NET methods, and LDAP.[3] The Windows utility Nltest is known to be used by adversaries to enumerate domain trusts.[4]

Mitigation.name: AdFind
Mitigation.description: AdFind can gather information about organizational units (OUs) and domain trusts from Active Directory.[5][6][7][8]

Mitigation.name: BADHATCH
Mitigation.description: BADHATCH can use nltest.exe /domain_trusts to discover domain trust relationships on a compromised machine.[9]

Mitigation.name: Bazar
Mitigation.description: Bazar can use Nltest tools to obtain information about the domain.[10][11]

Mitigation.name: BloodHound
Mitigation.description: BloodHound has the ability to map domain trusts and identify misconfigurations for potential abuse.[12]

Mitigation.name: Brute Ratel C4
Mitigation.description: Brute Ratel C4 can use LDAP queries and nltest /domain_trusts for domain trust discovery.[13][14]

Mitigation.name: C0015
Mitigation.description: During C0015, the threat actors used the command nltest /domain_trusts /all_trusts to enumerate domain trusts.[15]

Mitigation.name: Chimera
Mitigation.description: Chimera has nltest /domain_trusts to identify domain trust relationships.[16]

Mitigation.name: dsquery
Mitigation.description: dsquery can be used to gather information on domain trusts with dsquery * -filter "(objectClass=trustedDomain)" -attr *.[3]

Mitigation.name: Earth Lusca
Mitigation.description: Earth Lusca has used Nltest to obtain information about domain controllers.[17]

Mitigation.name: Empire
Mitigation.description: Empire has modules for enumerating domain trusts.[18]

Mitigation.name: FIN8
Mitigation.description: FIN8 has retrieved a list of trusted domains by using nltest.exe /domain_trusts.[19]

Mitigation.name: Magic Hound
Mitigation.description: Magic Hound has used a web shell to execute nltest /trusted_domains to identify trust relationships.[20]

Mitigation.name: Nltest
Mitigation.description: Nltest may be used to enumerate trusted domains by using commands such as nltest /domain_trusts.[21][22]

Mitigation.name: PoshC2
Mitigation.description: PoshC2 has modules for enumerating domain trusts.[23]

Mitigation.name: PowerSploit
Mitigation.description: PowerSploit has modules such as Get-NetDomainTrust and Get-NetForestTrust to enumerate domain and forest trusts.[24][25]

Mitigation.name: QakBot
Mitigation.description: QakBot can run nltest /domain_trusts /all_trusts for domain trust discovery.[26]

Mitigation.name: Rubeus
Mitigation.description: Rubeus can gather information about domain trusts.[27][28]

Mitigation.name: SolarWinds Compromise
Mitigation.description: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used the Get-AcceptedDomain PowerShell cmdlet to enumerate accepted domains through an Exchange Management Shell.[29] They also used AdFind to enumerate domains and to discover trust between federated domains.[30][31]

Mitigation.name: TrickBot
Mitigation.description: TrickBot can gather information about domain trusts by utilizing Nltest.[22][32]

Detection.detects: Monitor executed commands and arguments for actions that could be taken to gather system and network information, such as nltest /domain_trusts. Remote access tools with built-in features may interact directly with the Windows API to gather information.

Monitor and analyze traffic patterns and packet inspection associated to LDAP and MSRPC that do not follow the expected protocol standards and traffic flows (e.g extraneous packets that do not belong to established flows, gratuitous or anomalous traffic patterns, anomalous syntax, or structure).

Monitor for API calls associated with gathering information on domain trust relationships that may be used to identify lateral movement like DSEnumerateDomainTrusts() Win32 API call to spot activity associated with Domain Trust Discovery.[3] Information may also be acquired through Windows system management tools such as PowerShell. The .NET method GetAllTrustRelationships() can be an indicator of Domain Trust Discovery.[33]

Monitor for newly executed processes that may attempt to gather information on domain trust relationships that may be used to identify lateral movement opportunities in Windows multi-domain/forest environments.

Monitor for any attempts to enable scripts running on a system would be considered suspicious. If scripts are not commonly used on a system, but enabled, scripts running out of cycle from patching or other administrator functions are suspicious. Scripts should be captured from the file system when possible to determine their actions and intent.

Title: File and Directory Discovery
Description: Adversaries may enumerate files and directories or may search in specific locations of a host or network share for certain information within a file system. Adversaries may use the information from File and Directory Discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.Many command shell utilities can be used to obtain this information. Examples include dir, tree, ls, find, and locate.[1] Custom tools may also be used to gather file and directory information and interact with the Native API. Adversaries may also leverage a Network Device CLI on network devices to gather file and directory information (e.g. dir, show flash, and/or nvram).[2]

Mitigation.name: 3PARA RAT
Mitigation.description: 3PARA RAT has a command to retrieve metadata for files on disk as well as a command to list the current working directory.[3]

Mitigation.name: 4H RAT
Mitigation.description: 4H RAT has the capability to obtain file and directory listings.[3]

Mitigation.name: Action RAT
Mitigation.description: Action RAT has the ability to collect drive and file information on an infected machine.[4]

Mitigation.name: admin@338
Mitigation.description: admin@338 actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with LOWBALL malware to obtain information about files and directories: dir c:\ >> %temp%\download dir "c:\Documents and Settings" >> %temp%\download dir "c:\Program Files\" >> %temp%\download dir d:\ >> %temp%\download[5]

Mitigation.name: ADVSTORESHELL
Mitigation.description: ADVSTORESHELL can list files and directories.[6][7]

Mitigation.name: Amadey
Mitigation.description: Amadey has searched for folders associated with antivirus software.[8]

Mitigation.name: Aoqin Dragon
Mitigation.description: Aoqin Dragon has run scripts to identify file formats including Microsoft Word.[9]

Mitigation.name: AppleSeed
Mitigation.description: AppleSeed has the ability to search for .txt, .ppt, .hwp, .pdf, and .doc files in specified directories.[10]

Mitigation.name: APT18
Mitigation.description: APT18 can list files information for specific directories.[11]

Mitigation.name: APT28
Mitigation.description: APT28 has used Forfiles to locate PDF, Excel, and Word documents during collection. The group also searched a compromised DCCC computer for specific terms.[12][13]

Mitigation.name: APT3
Mitigation.description: APT3 has a tool that looks for files and directories on the local file system.[14][15]

Mitigation.name: APT32
Mitigation.description: APT32's backdoor possesses the capability to list files and directories on a machine. [16]

Mitigation.name: APT38
Mitigation.description: APT38 have enumerated files and directories, or searched in specific locations within a compromised host.[17]

Mitigation.name: APT39
Mitigation.description: APT39 has used tools with the ability to search for files on a compromised host.[18]

Mitigation.name: APT41
Mitigation.description: APT41 has executed file /bin/pwd on exploited victims, perhaps to return architecture related information.[19]

Mitigation.name: Aria-body
Mitigation.description: Aria-body has the ability to gather metadata from a file and to search for file and directory names.[20]

Mitigation.name: Attor
Mitigation.description: Attor has a plugin that enumerates files with specific extensions on all hard disk drives and stores file information in encrypted log files.[21]

Mitigation.name: AuditCred
Mitigation.description: AuditCred can search through folders and files on the system.[22]

Mitigation.name: AutoIt backdoor
Mitigation.description: AutoIt backdoor is capable of identifying documents on the victim with the following extensions: .doc; .pdf, .csv, .ppt, .docx, .pst, .xls, .xlsx, .pptx, and .jpeg.[23]

Mitigation.name: Avaddon
Mitigation.description: Avaddon has searched for specific files prior to encryption.[24]

Mitigation.name: Avenger
Mitigation.description: Avenger has the ability to browse files in directories such as Program Files and the Desktop.[25]

Mitigation.name: AvosLocker
Mitigation.description: AvosLocker has searched for files and directories on a compromised network.[26][27]

Mitigation.name: Azorult
Mitigation.description: Azorult can recursively search for files in folders and collects files from the desktop with certain extensions.[28]

Mitigation.name: Babuk
Mitigation.description: Babuk has the ability to enumerate files on a targeted system.[29][30]

Mitigation.name: BabyShark
Mitigation.description: BabyShark has used dir to search for "programfiles" and "appdata".[31]

Mitigation.name: BackConfig
Mitigation.description: BackConfig has the ability to identify folders and files related to previous infections.[32]

Mitigation.name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Mitigation.description: Backdoor.Oldrea collects information about available drives, default browser, desktop file list, My Documents, Internet history, program files, and root of available drives. It also searches for ICS-related software files.[33]

Mitigation.name: BACKSPACE
Mitigation.description: BACKSPACE allows adversaries to search for files.[34]

Mitigation.name: BADFLICK
Mitigation.description: BADFLICK has searched for files on the infected host.[35]

Mitigation.name: BADNEWS
Mitigation.description: BADNEWS identifies files with certain extensions from USB devices, then copies them to a predefined directory.[36]

Mitigation.name: BadPatch
Mitigation.description: BadPatch searches for files with specific file extensions.[37]

Mitigation.name: Bandook
Mitigation.description: Bandook has a command to list files on a system.[38]

Mitigation.name: Bankshot
Mitigation.description: Bankshot searches for files on the victim's machine.[39]

Mitigation.name: Bazar
Mitigation.description: Bazar can enumerate the victim's desktop.[40][41]

Mitigation.name: BBSRAT
Mitigation.description: BBSRAT can list file and directory information.[42]

Mitigation.name: Bisonal
Mitigation.description: Bisonal can retrieve a file listing from the system.[43][44]

Mitigation.name: Black Basta
Mitigation.description: Black Basta can enumerate specific files for encryption.[45][46][47][48][49][50][51][52]

Mitigation.name: BlackCat
Mitigation.description: BlackCat can enumerate files for encryption.[53]

Mitigation.name: BLACKCOFFEE
Mitigation.description: BLACKCOFFEE has the capability to enumerate files.[54]

Mitigation.name: BlackEnergy
Mitigation.description: BlackEnergy gathers a list of installed apps from the uninstall program Registry. It also gathers registered mail, browser, and instant messaging clients from the Registry. BlackEnergy has searched for given file types.[55][56]

Mitigation.name: BlackMould
Mitigation.description: BlackMould has the ability to find files on the targeted system.[57]

Mitigation.name: BLINDINGCAN
Mitigation.description: BLINDINGCAN can search, read, write, move, and execute files.[58][59]

Mitigation.name: BLUELIGHT
Mitigation.description: BLUELIGHT can enumerate files and collect associated metadata.[60]

Mitigation.name: BoomBox
Mitigation.description: BoomBox can search for specific files and directories on a machine.[61]

Mitigation.name: BoxCaon
Mitigation.description: BoxCaon has searched for files on the system, such as documents located in the desktop folder.[62]

Mitigation.name: Brave Prince
Mitigation.description: Brave Prince gathers file and directory information from the victims machine.[63]

Mitigation.name: BRONZE BUTLER
Mitigation.description: BRONZE BUTLER has collected a list of files from the victim and uploaded it to its C2 server, and then created a new list of specific files to steal.[64]

Mitigation.name: C0015
Mitigation.description: During C0015, the threat actors conducted a file listing discovery against multiple hosts to ensure locker encryption was successful.[65]

Mitigation.name: CaddyWiper
Mitigation.description: CaddyWiper can enumerate all files and directories on a compromised host.[66]

Mitigation.name: Cannon
Mitigation.description: Cannon can obtain victim drive information as well as a list of folders in C:\Program Files.[67]

Mitigation.name: Cardinal RAT
Mitigation.description: Cardinal RAT checks its current working directory upon execution and also contains watchdog functionality that ensures its executable is located in the correct path (else it will rewrite the payload).[68]

Mitigation.name: Caterpillar WebShell
Mitigation.description: Caterpillar WebShell can search for files in directories.[69]

Mitigation.name: ccf32
Mitigation.description: ccf32 can parse collected files to identify specific file extensions.[70]

Mitigation.name: CharmPower
Mitigation.description: CharmPower can enumerate drives and list the contents of the C: drive on a victim's computer.[71]

Mitigation.name: ChChes
Mitigation.description: ChChes collects the victim's %TEMP% directory path and version of Internet Explorer.[72]

Mitigation.name: Chimera
Mitigation.description: Chimera has utilized multiple commands to identify data of interest in file and directory listings.[73]

Mitigation.name: China Chopper
Mitigation.description: China Chopper's server component can list directory contents.[74][75]

Mitigation.name: CHOPSTICK
Mitigation.description: An older version of CHOPSTICK has a module that monitors all mounted volumes for files with the extensions .doc, .docx, .pgp, .gpg, .m2f, or .m2o.[6]

Mitigation.name: Clambling
Mitigation.description: Clambling can browse directories on a compromised host.[76][77]

Mitigation.name: Clop
Mitigation.description: Clop has searched folders and subfolders for files to encrypt.[78]

Mitigation.name: cmd
Mitigation.description: cmd can be used to find files and directories with native functionality such as dir commands.[79]

Mitigation.name: Cobalt Strike
Mitigation.description: Cobalt Strike can explore files on a compromised system.[80]

Mitigation.name: Confucius
Mitigation.description: Confucius has used a file stealer that checks the Document, Downloads, Desktop, and Picture folders for documents and images with specific extensions.[81]

Mitigation.name: Conti
Mitigation.description: Conti can discover files on a local system.[82]

Mitigation.name: CookieMiner
Mitigation.description: CookieMiner has looked for files in the user's home directory with "wallet" in their name using find.[83]

Mitigation.name: CORALDECK
Mitigation.description: CORALDECK searches for specified files.[84]

Mitigation.name: CosmicDuke
Mitigation.description: CosmicDuke searches attached and mounted drives for file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.[85]

Mitigation.name: CrackMapExec
Mitigation.description: CrackMapExec can discover specified filetypes and log files on a targeted system.[86]

Mitigation.name: CreepyDrive
Mitigation.description: CreepyDrive can specify the local file path to upload files from.[87]

Mitigation.name: Crimson
Mitigation.description: Crimson contains commands to list files and directories, as well as search for files matching certain extensions from a defined list.[88][89][90]

Mitigation.name: CrossRAT
Mitigation.description: CrossRAT can list all files on a system.[91]

Mitigation.name: Cryptoistic
Mitigation.description: Cryptoistic can scan a directory to identify files for deletion.[92]

Mitigation.name: Cuba
Mitigation.description: Cuba can enumerate files by using a variety of functions.[93]

Mitigation.name: Cyclops Blink
Mitigation.description: Cyclops Blink can use the Linux API statvfs to enumerate the current working directory.[94][95]

Mitigation.name: Dacls
Mitigation.description: Dacls can scan directories on a compromised host.[96]

Mitigation.name: Dark Caracal
Mitigation.description: Dark Caracal collected file listings of all default Windows directories.[91]

Mitigation.name: Darkhotel
Mitigation.description: Darkhotel has used malware that searched for files with specific patterns.[97]

Mitigation.name: DarkWatchman
Mitigation.description: DarkWatchman has the ability to enumerate file and folder names.[98]

Mitigation.name: DDKONG
Mitigation.description: DDKONG lists files on the victims machine.[99]

Mitigation.name: DEATHRANSOM
Mitigation.description: DEATHRANSOM can use loop operations to enumerate directories on a compromised host.[100]

Mitigation.name: Denis
Mitigation.description: Denis has several commands to search directories for files.[101][102]

Mitigation.name: Derusbi
Mitigation.description: Derusbi is capable of obtaining directory, file, and drive listings.[103][74]

Mitigation.name: Diavol
Mitigation.description: Diavol has a command to traverse the files and directories in a given path.[104]

Mitigation.name: Doki
Mitigation.description: Doki has resolved the path of a process PID to use as a script argument.[105]

Mitigation.name: down_new
Mitigation.description: down_new has the ability to list the directories on a compromised host.[25]

Mitigation.name: Dragonfly
Mitigation.description: Dragonfly has used a batch script to gather folder and file names from victim hosts.[106][107][108]

Mitigation.name: DropBook
Mitigation.description: DropBook can collect the names of all files and folders in the Program Files directories.[109][110]

Mitigation.name: Dtrack
Mitigation.description: Dtrack can list files on available disk volumes.[111][112]

Mitigation.name: DustySky
Mitigation.description: DustySky scans the victim for files that contain certain keywords and document types including PDF, DOC, DOCX, XLS, and XLSX, from a list that is obtained from the C2 as a text file. It can also identify logical drives for the infected machine.[113][114]

Mitigation.name: Ebury
Mitigation.description: Ebury can list directory entries.[115]

Mitigation.name: Elise
Mitigation.description: A variant of Elise executes dir C:\progra~1 when initially run.[116][117]

Mitigation.name: ELMER
Mitigation.description: ELMER is capable of performing directory listings.[118]

Mitigation.name: Empire
Mitigation.description: Empire includes various modules for finding files of interest on hosts and network shares.[119]

Mitigation.name: Epic
Mitigation.description: Epic recursively searches for all .doc files on the system and collects a directory listing of the Desktop, %TEMP%, and %WINDOWS%\Temp directories.[120][121]

Mitigation.name: FALLCHILL
Mitigation.description: FALLCHILL can search files on a victim.[122]

Mitigation.name: FatDuke
Mitigation.description: FatDuke can enumerate directories on target machines.[123]

Mitigation.name: FIN13
Mitigation.description: FIN13 has used the Windows dir command to enumerate files and directories in a victim's network.[124]

Mitigation.name: FinFisher
Mitigation.description: FinFisher enumerates directories and scans for certain files.[125][126]

Mitigation.name: FIVEHANDS
Mitigation.description: FIVEHANDS has the ability to enumerate files on a compromised host in order to encrypt files with specific extensions.[127][128]

Mitigation.name: FLASHFLOOD
Mitigation.description: FLASHFLOOD searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system and removable media.[34]

Mitigation.name: FoggyWeb
Mitigation.description: FoggyWeb's loader can check for the FoggyWeb backdoor .pri file on a compromised AD FS server.[129]

Mitigation.name: Forfiles
Mitigation.description: Forfiles can be used to locate certain types of files/directories in a system.(ex: locate all files with a specific extension, name, and/or age)[12]

Mitigation.name: Fox Kitten
Mitigation.description: Fox Kitten has used WizTree to obtain network files and directory listings.[130]

Mitigation.name: FruitFly
Mitigation.description: FruitFly looks for specific files and file types.[131]

Mitigation.name: FunnyDream
Mitigation.description: FunnyDream can identify files with .doc, .docx, .ppt, .pptx, .xls, .xlsx, and .pdf extensions and specific timestamps for collection.[70]

Mitigation.name: FYAnti
Mitigation.description: FYAnti can search the C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\ directory for files of a specified size.[132]

Mitigation.name: Fysbis
Mitigation.description: Fysbis has the ability to search for files.[133]

Mitigation.name: Gamaredon Group
Mitigation.description: Gamaredon Group macros can scan for Microsoft Word and Excel files to inject with additional malicious macros. Gamaredon Group has also used its backdoors to automatically list interesting files (such as Office documents) found on a system.[134][135]

Mitigation.name: Gelsemium
Mitigation.description: Gelsemium can retrieve data from specific Windows directories, as well as open random files as part of Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion.[136]

Mitigation.name: GeminiDuke
Mitigation.description: GeminiDuke collects information from the victim, including installed drivers, programs previously executed by users, programs and services configured to automatically run at startup, files and folders present in any user's home folder, files and folders present in any user's My Documents, programs installed to the Program Files folder, and recently accessed files, folders, and programs.[137]

Mitigation.name: Gold Dragon
Mitigation.description: Gold Dragon lists the directories for Desktop, program files, and the users recently accessed files.[63]

Mitigation.name: GoldenSpy
Mitigation.description: GoldenSpy has included a program "ExeProtector", which monitors for the existence of GoldenSpy on the infected system and redownloads if necessary.[138]

Mitigation.name: GravityRAT
Mitigation.description: GravityRAT collects the volumes mapped on the system, and also steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.[139]

Mitigation.name: GrimAgent
Mitigation.description: GrimAgent has the ability to enumerate files and directories on a compromised host.[140]

Mitigation.name: HAFNIUM
Mitigation.description: HAFNIUM has searched file contents on a compromised host.[75]

Mitigation.name: HermeticWiper
Mitigation.description: HermeticWiper can enumerate common folders such as My Documents, Desktop, and AppData.[141][142]

Mitigation.name: Heyoka Backdoor
Mitigation.description: Heyoka Backdoor has the ability to search the compromised host for files.[9]

Mitigation.name: HOPLIGHT
Mitigation.description: HOPLIGHT has been observed enumerating system drives and partitions.[143]

Mitigation.name: HotCroissant
Mitigation.description: HotCroissant has the ability to retrieve a list of files in a given directory as well as drives and drive types.[144]

Mitigation.name: HTTPBrowser
Mitigation.description: HTTPBrowser is capable of listing files, folders, and drives on a victim.[145][146]

Mitigation.name: Hydraq
Mitigation.description: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can check for the existence of files, including its own components, as well as retrieve a list of logical drives.[147][148]

Mitigation.name: IceApple
Mitigation.description: The IceApple Directory Lister module can list information about files and directories including creation time, last write time, name, and size.[149]

Mitigation.name: Imminent Monitor
Mitigation.description: Imminent Monitor has a dynamic debugging feature to check whether it is located in the %TEMP% directory, otherwise it copies itself there.[150]

Mitigation.name: Inception
Mitigation.description: Inception used a file listing plugin to collect information about file and directories both on local and remote drives.[151]

Mitigation.name: Industroyer
Mitigation.description: Industroyers data wiper component enumerates specific files on all the Windows drives.[152]

Mitigation.name: InnaputRAT
Mitigation.description: InnaputRAT enumerates directories and obtains file attributes on a system.[153]

Mitigation.name: InvisiMole
Mitigation.description: InvisiMole can list information about files in a directory and recently opened or used documents. InvisiMole can also search for specific files by supplied file mask.[154]

Mitigation.name: Ixeshe
Mitigation.description: Ixeshe can list file and directory information.[155]

Mitigation.name: JPIN
Mitigation.description: JPIN can enumerate drives and their types. It can also change file permissions using cacls.exe.[156]

Mitigation.name: jRAT
Mitigation.description: jRAT can browse file systems.[157][158]

Mitigation.name: Kasidet
Mitigation.description: Kasidet has the ability to search for a given filename on a victim.[159]

Mitigation.name: Kazuar
Mitigation.description: Kazuar finds a specified directory, lists the files and metadata about those files.[160]

Mitigation.name: Ke3chang
Mitigation.description: Ke3chang uses command-line interaction to search files and directories.[161][162]

Mitigation.name: KeyBoy
Mitigation.description: KeyBoy has a command to launch a file browser or explorer on the system.[163]

Mitigation.name: KEYMARBLE
Mitigation.description: KEYMARBLE has a command to search for files on the victims machine.[164]

Mitigation.name: KGH_SPY
Mitigation.description: KGH_SPY can enumerate files and directories on a compromised host.[165]

Mitigation.name: KillDisk
Mitigation.description: KillDisk has used the FindNextFile command as part of its file deletion process.[166]

Mitigation.name: Kimsuky
Mitigation.description: Kimsuky has the ability to enumerate all files and directories on an infected system.[167][168][169]

Mitigation.name: Kinsing
Mitigation.description: Kinsing has used the find command to search for specific files.[170]

Mitigation.name: Kivars
Mitigation.description: Kivars has the ability to list drives on the infected host.[171]

Mitigation.name: Koadic
Mitigation.description: Koadic can obtain a list of directories.[172]

Mitigation.name: KONNI
Mitigation.description: A version of KONNI searches for filenames created with a previous version of the malware, suggesting different versions targeted the same victims and the versions may work together.[173]

Mitigation.name: Kwampirs
Mitigation.description: Kwampirs collects a list of files and directories in C:\ with the command dir /s /a c:\ >> "C:\windows\TEMP[RANDOM].tmp".[174]

Mitigation.name: Lazarus Group
Mitigation.description: Lazarus Group malware can use a common function to identify target files by their extension, and some also enumerate files and directories, including a Destover-like variant that lists files and gathers information for all drives.[175][176][177][178]

Mitigation.name: Leafminer
Mitigation.description: Leafminer used a tool called MailSniper to search for files on the desktop and another utility called Sobolsoft to extract attachments from EML files.[179]

Mitigation.name: Linfo
Mitigation.description: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can list contents of drives and search for files.[180]

Mitigation.name: Lokibot
Mitigation.description: Lokibot can search for specific files on an infected host.[181]

Mitigation.name: LookBack
Mitigation.description: LookBack can retrieve file listings from the victim machine.[182]

Mitigation.name: LuminousMoth
Mitigation.description: LuminousMoth has used malware that scans for files in the Documents, Desktop, and Download folders and in other drives.[183][184]

Mitigation.name: Machete
Mitigation.description: Machete produces file listings in order to search for files to be exfiltrated.[185][186][187]

Mitigation.name: MacMa
Mitigation.description: MacMa can search for a specific file on the compromised computer and can enumerate files in Desktop, Downloads, and Documents folders.[188]

Mitigation.name: Mafalda
Mitigation.description: Mafalda can search for files and directories.[189]

Mitigation.name: Magic Hound
Mitigation.description: Magic Hound malware can list a victim's logical drives and the type, as well the total/free space of the fixed devices. Other malware can list a directory's contents.[190]

Mitigation.name: MarkiRAT
Mitigation.description: MarkiRAT can look for files carrying specific extensions such as: .rtf, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .ppt, .pptx, .pps, .ppsx, .txt, .gpg, .pkr, .kdbx, .key, and .jpb.[191]

Mitigation.name: MegaCortex
Mitigation.description: MegaCortex can parse the available drives and directories to determine which files to encrypt.[192]

Mitigation.name: menuPass
Mitigation.description: menuPass has searched compromised systems for folders of interest including those related to HR, audit and expense, and meeting memos.[193]

Mitigation.name: MESSAGETAP
Mitigation.description: MESSAGETAP checks for the existence of two configuration files (keyword_parm.txt and parm.txt) and attempts to read the files every 30 seconds.[194]

Mitigation.name: metaMain
Mitigation.description: metaMain can recursively enumerate files in an operator-provided directory.[189][195]

Mitigation.name: Metamorfo
Mitigation.description: Metamorfo has searched the Program Files directories for specific folders and has searched for strings related to its mutexes.[196][197][198]

Mitigation.name: Micropsia
Mitigation.description: Micropsia can perform a recursive directory listing for all volume drives available on the victim's machine and can also fetch specific files by their paths.[199]

Mitigation.name: MiniDuke
Mitigation.description: MiniDuke can enumerate local drives.[123]

Mitigation.name: Misdat
Mitigation.description: Misdat is capable of running commands to obtain a list of files and directories, as well as enumerating logical drives.[200]

Mitigation.name: MobileOrder
Mitigation.description: MobileOrder has a command to upload to its C2 server information about files on the victim mobile device, including SD card size, installed app list, SMS content, contacts, and calling history.[201]

Mitigation.name: MoonWind
Mitigation.description: MoonWind has a command to return a directory listing for a specified directory.[202]

Mitigation.name: MuddyWater
Mitigation.description: MuddyWater has used malware that checked if the ProgramData folder had folders or files with the keywords "Kasper," "Panda," or "ESET."[203]

Mitigation.name: Mustang Panda
Mitigation.description: Mustang Panda has searched the entire target system for DOC, DOCX, PPT, PPTX, XLS, XLSX, and PDF files.[204]

Mitigation.name: NDiskMonitor
Mitigation.description: NDiskMonitor can obtain a list of all files and directories as well as logical drives.[36]

Mitigation.name: Nebulae
Mitigation.description: Nebulae can list files and directories on a compromised host.[205]

Mitigation.name: NETEAGLE
Mitigation.description: NETEAGLE allows adversaries to enumerate and modify the infected host's file system. It supports searching for directories, creating directories, listing directory contents, reading and writing to files, retrieving file attributes, and retrieving volume information.[34]

Mitigation.name: NETWIRE
Mitigation.description: NETWIRE has the ability to search for files on the compromised host.[206]

Mitigation.name: Night Dragon
Mitigation.description: During Night Dragon, threat actors used zwShell to establish full remote control of the connected machine and browse the victim file system.[207]

Mitigation.name: NightClub
Mitigation.description: NightClub can use a file monitor to identify .lnk, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xslx, and .pdf files.[208]

Mitigation.name: njRAT
Mitigation.description: njRAT can browse file systems using a file manager module.[209]

Mitigation.name: NotPetya
Mitigation.description: NotPetya searches for files ending with dozens of different file extensions prior to encryption.[210]

Mitigation.name: ObliqueRAT
Mitigation.description: ObliqueRAT has the ability to recursively enumerate files on an infected endpoint.[211]

Mitigation.name: OceanSalt
Mitigation.description: OceanSalt can extract drive information from the endpoint and search files on the system.[212]

Mitigation.name: Octopus
Mitigation.description: Octopus can collect information on the Windows directory and searches for compressed RAR files on the host.[213][214][215]

Mitigation.name: Okrum
Mitigation.description: Okrum has used DriveLetterView to enumerate drive information.[216]

Mitigation.name: Operation CuckooBees
Mitigation.description: During Operation CuckooBees, the threat actors used dir c:\\ to search for files.[217]

Mitigation.name: Operation Dream Job
Mitigation.description: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group conducted word searches within documents on a compromised host in search of security and financial matters.[218]

Mitigation.name: Operation Honeybee
Mitigation.description: During Operation Honeybee, the threat actors used a malicious DLL to search for files with specific keywords.[219]

Mitigation.name: Operation Wocao
Mitigation.description: During Operation Wocao, threat actors gathered a recursive directory listing to find files and directories of interest.[220]

Mitigation.name: Orz
Mitigation.description: Orz can gather victim drive information.[221]

Mitigation.name: OSX/Shlayer
Mitigation.description: OSX/Shlayer has used the command appDir="$(dirname $(dirname "$currentDir"))" and $(dirname "$(pwd -P)") to construct installation paths.[222][223]

Mitigation.name: OutSteel
Mitigation.description: OutSteel can search for specific file extensions, including zipped files.[224]

Mitigation.name: OwaAuth
Mitigation.description: OwaAuth has a command to list its directory and logical drives.[145]

Mitigation.name: P.A.S. Webshell
Mitigation.description: P.A.S. Webshell has the ability to list files and file characteristics including extension, size, ownership, and permissions.[225]

Mitigation.name: Pasam
Mitigation.description: Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve lists of files.[226]

Mitigation.name: Patchwork
Mitigation.description: A Patchwork payload has searched all fixed drives on the victim for files matching a specified list of extensions.[227][36]

Mitigation.name: Penquin
Mitigation.description: Penquin can use the command code do_vslist to send file names, size, and status to C2.[228]

Mitigation.name: Peppy
Mitigation.description: Peppy can identify specific files for exfiltration.[88]

Mitigation.name: PinchDuke
Mitigation.description: PinchDuke searches for files created within a certain timeframe and whose file extension matches a predefined list.[137]

Mitigation.name: PingPull
Mitigation.description: PingPull can enumerate storage volumes and folder contents of a compromised host.[229]

Mitigation.name: Pisloader
Mitigation.description: Pisloader has commands to list drives on the victim machine and to list file information for a given directory.[230]

Mitigation.name: PLEAD
Mitigation.description: PLEAD has the ability to list drives and files on the compromised host.[171][231]

Mitigation.name: PlugX
Mitigation.description: PlugX has a module to enumerate drives and find files recursively.[232][233]

Mitigation.name: PoetRAT
Mitigation.description: PoetRAT has the ability to list files upon receiving the ls command from C2.[234]

Mitigation.name: POORAIM
Mitigation.description: POORAIM can conduct file browsing.[84]

Mitigation.name: PoshC2
Mitigation.description: PoshC2 can enumerate files on the local file system and includes a module for enumerating recently accessed files.[235]

Mitigation.name: PowerDuke
Mitigation.description: PowerDuke has commands to get the current directory name as well as the size of a file. It also has commands to obtain information about logical drives, drive type, and free space.[236]

Mitigation.name: POWRUNER
Mitigation.description: POWRUNER may enumerate user directories on a victim.[237]

Mitigation.name: Prestige
Mitigation.description: Prestige can traverse the file system to discover files to encrypt by identifying specific extensions defined in a hardcoded list.[238]

Mitigation.name: Prikormka
Mitigation.description: A module in Prikormka collects information about the paths, size, and creation time of files with specific file extensions, but not the actual content of the file.[239]

Mitigation.name: Proxysvc
Mitigation.description: Proxysvc lists files in directories.[176]

Mitigation.name: Psylo
Mitigation.description: Psylo has commands to enumerate all storage devices and to find all files that start with a particular string.[201]

Mitigation.name: Pteranodon
Mitigation.description: Pteranodon identifies files matching certain file extension and copies them to subdirectories it created.[240]

Mitigation.name: Pupy
Mitigation.description: Pupy can walk through directories and recursively search for strings in files.[241]

Mitigation.name: QakBot
Mitigation.description: QakBot can identify whether it has been run previously on a host by checking for a specified folder.[242]

Mitigation.name: QuietSieve
Mitigation.description: QuietSieve can search files on the target host by extension, including doc, docx, xls, rtf, odt, txt, jpg, pdf, rar, zip, and 7z.[243]

Mitigation.name: RainyDay
Mitigation.description: RainyDay can use a file exfiltration tool to collect recently changed files with specific extensions.[205]

Mitigation.name: Ramsay
Mitigation.description: Ramsay can collect directory and file lists.[244][245]

Mitigation.name: RARSTONE
Mitigation.description: RARSTONE obtains installer properties from Uninstall Registry Key entries to obtain information about installed applications and how to uninstall certain applications.[246]

Mitigation.name: Rclone
Mitigation.description: Rclone can list files and directories with the ls, lsd, and lsl commands.[247]

Mitigation.name: RedLeaves
Mitigation.description: RedLeaves can enumerate and search for files and directories.[248][72]

Mitigation.name: Remcos
Mitigation.description: Remcos can search for files on the infected machine.[249]

Mitigation.name: Remexi
Mitigation.description: Remexi searches for files on the system. [250]

Mitigation.name: RemoteUtilities
Mitigation.description: RemoteUtilities can enumerate files and directories on a target machine.[251]

Mitigation.name: Remsec
Mitigation.description: Remsec is capable of listing contents of folders on the victim. Remsec also searches for custom network encryption software on victims.[252][253][254]

Mitigation.name: REvil
Mitigation.description: REvil has the ability to identify specific files and directories that are not to be encrypted.[255][256][257][258][259][260]

Mitigation.name: Rising Sun
Mitigation.description: Rising Sun can enumerate information about files from the infected system, including file size, attributes, creation time, last access time, and write time. Rising Sun can enumerate the compilation timestamp of Windows executable files.[261]

Mitigation.name: ROKRAT
Mitigation.description: ROKRAT has the ability to gather a list of files and directories on the infected system.[262][263][264]

Mitigation.name: Rover
Mitigation.description: Rover automatically searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions.[265]

Mitigation.name: Royal
Mitigation.description: Royal can identify specific files and directories to exclude from the encryption process.[266][267][268]

Mitigation.name: RTM
Mitigation.description: RTM can check for specific files and directories associated with virtualization and malware analysis.[269]

Mitigation.name: Ryuk
Mitigation.description: Ryuk has enumerated files and folders on all mounted drives.[270]

Mitigation.name: Saint Bot
Mitigation.description: Saint Bot can search a compromised host for specific files.[224]

Mitigation.name: Sandworm Team
Mitigation.description: Sandworm Team has enumerated files on a compromised host.[210][271]

Mitigation.name: SDBbot
Mitigation.description: SDBbot has the ability to get directory listings or drive information on a compromised host.[272]

Mitigation.name: Seasalt
Mitigation.description: Seasalt has the capability to identify the drive type on a victim.[212]

Mitigation.name: SharpDisco
Mitigation.description: SharpDisco can identify recently opened files by using an LNK format parser to extract the original file path from LNK files found in either %USERPROFILE%\Recent (Windows XP) or %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Recent (newer Windows versions) .[208]

Mitigation.name: ShimRat
Mitigation.description: ShimRat can list directories.[273]

Mitigation.name: SHOTPUT
Mitigation.description: SHOTPUT has a command to obtain a directory listing.[274]

Mitigation.name: SideTwist
Mitigation.description: SideTwist has the ability to search for specific files.[275]

Mitigation.name: Sidewinder
Mitigation.description: Sidewinder has used malware to collect information on files and directories.[276]

Mitigation.name: SILENTTRINITY
Mitigation.description: SILENTTRINITY has several modules, such as ls.py, pwd.py, and recentFiles.py, to enumerate directories and files.[277]

Mitigation.name: Siloscape
Mitigation.description: Siloscape searches for the Kubernetes config file and other related files using a regular expression.[278]

Mitigation.name: Skidmap
Mitigation.description: Skidmap has checked for the existence of specific files including /usr/sbin/setenforce and  /etc/selinux/config. It also has the ability to monitor the cryptocurrency miner file and process. [279]

Mitigation.name: Sliver
Mitigation.description: Sliver can enumerate files on a target system.[280]

Mitigation.name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Mitigation.description: SLOTHFULMEDIA can enumerate files and directories.[281]

Mitigation.name: Smoke Loader
Mitigation.description: Smoke Loader recursively searches through directories for files.[282]

Mitigation.name: SolarWinds Compromise
Mitigation.description: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 obtained information about the configured Exchange virtual directory using Get-WebServicesVirtualDirectory.[283]

Mitigation.name: SombRAT
Mitigation.description: SombRAT can execute enum to enumerate files in storage on a compromised system.[284]

Mitigation.name: SoreFang
Mitigation.description: SoreFang has the ability to list directories.[285]

Mitigation.name: SOUNDBITE
Mitigation.description: SOUNDBITE is capable of enumerating and manipulating files and directories.[286]

Mitigation.name: Sowbug
Mitigation.description: Sowbug identified and extracted all Word documents on a server by using a command containing * .doc and *.docx. The actors also searched for documents based on a specific date range and attempted to identify all installed software on a victim.[287]

Mitigation.name: SPACESHIP
Mitigation.description: SPACESHIP identifies files and directories for collection by searching for specific file extensions or file modification time.[34]

Mitigation.name: StreamEx
Mitigation.description: StreamEx has the ability to enumerate drive types.[288]

Mitigation.name: StrifeWater
Mitigation.description: StrifeWater can enumerate files on a compromised host.[289]

Mitigation.name: StrongPity
Mitigation.description: StrongPity can parse the hard drive on a compromised host to identify specific file extensions.[290]

Mitigation.name: Stuxnet
Mitigation.description: Stuxnet uses a driver to scan for specific filesystem driver objects.[291]

Mitigation.name: SUGARDUMP
Mitigation.description: SUGARDUMP can search for and collect data from specific Chrome, Opera, Microsoft Edge, and Firefox files, including any folders that have the string Profile in its name.[292]

Mitigation.name: SUNBURST
Mitigation.description: SUNBURST had commands to enumerate files and directories.[293][294]

Mitigation.name: SUNSPOT
Mitigation.description: SUNSPOT enumerated the Orion software Visual Studio solution directory path.[295]

Mitigation.name: SynAck
Mitigation.description: SynAck checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.[296][297]

Mitigation.name: SysUpdate
Mitigation.description: SysUpdate can search files on a compromised host.[298][299]

Mitigation.name: Taidoor
Mitigation.description: Taidoor can search for specific files.[300]

Mitigation.name: TAINTEDSCRIBE
Mitigation.description: TAINTEDSCRIBE can use DirectoryList to enumerate files in a specified directory.[301]

Mitigation.name: TajMahal
Mitigation.description: TajMahal has the ability to index files from drives, user profiles, and removable drives.[302]

Mitigation.name: TeamTNT
Mitigation.description: TeamTNT has used a script that checks /proc/*/environ for environment variables related to AWS.[303]

Mitigation.name: ThreatNeedle
Mitigation.description: ThreatNeedle can obtain file and directory information.[304]

Mitigation.name: TINYTYPHON
Mitigation.description: TINYTYPHON searches through the drive containing the OS, then all drive letters C through to Z, for documents matching certain extensions.[23]

Mitigation.name: TrickBot
Mitigation.description: TrickBot searches the system for all of the following file extensions: .avi, .mov, .mkv, .mpeg, .mpeg4, .mp4, .mp3, .wav, .ogg, .jpeg, .jpg, .png, .bmp, .gif, .tiff, .ico, .xlsx, and .zip. It can also obtain browsing history, cookies, and plug-in information.[305][306]

Mitigation.name: Trojan.Karagany
Mitigation.description: Trojan.Karagany can enumerate files and directories on a compromised host.[307]

Mitigation.name: Tropic Trooper
Mitigation.description: Tropic Trooper has monitored files' modified time.[308]

Mitigation.name: TSCookie
Mitigation.description: TSCookie has the ability to discover drive information on the infected host.[309]

Mitigation.name: Turian
Mitigation.description: Turian can search for specific files and list directories.[310]

Mitigation.name: Turla
Mitigation.description: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover files in specific locations on the hard disk %TEMP% directory, the current user's desktop, the Program Files directory, and Recent.[120][311] Turla RPC backdoors have also searched for files matching the lPH*.dll pattern.[312]

Mitigation.name: TYPEFRAME
Mitigation.description: TYPEFRAME can search directories for files on the victims machine.[313]

Mitigation.name: UPPERCUT
Mitigation.description: UPPERCUT has the capability to gather the victim's current directory.[314]

Mitigation.name: Uroburos
Mitigation.description: Uroburos can search for specific files on a compromised system.[315]

Mitigation.name: USBferry
Mitigation.description: USBferry can detect the victim's file or folder list.[308]

Mitigation.name: USBStealer
Mitigation.description: USBStealer searches victim drives for files matching certain extensions (".skr",".pkr" or ".key") or names.[316][317]

Mitigation.name: Volgmer
Mitigation.description: Volgmer can list directories on a victim.[318]

Mitigation.name: WannaCry
Mitigation.description: WannaCry searches for variety of user files by file extension before encrypting them using RSA and AES, including Office, PDF, image, audio, video, source code, archive/compression format, and key and certificate files.[319][320]

Mitigation.name: WarzoneRAT
Mitigation.description: WarzoneRAT can enumerate directories on a compromise host.[321]

Mitigation.name: WastedLocker
Mitigation.description: WastedLocker can enumerate files and directories just prior to encryption.[322]

Mitigation.name: WhisperGate
Mitigation.description: WhisperGate can locate files based on hardcoded file extensions.[323][324][325][326]

Mitigation.name: Windigo
Mitigation.description: Windigo has used a script to check for the presence of files created by OpenSSH backdoors.[327]

Mitigation.name: WindTail
